If the current through the motor is held constant, the relationship between torque and inductance will be different than what I described earlier. In this case, the torque produced by the motor will be directly proportional to the inductance of the windings.

This is because, with a constant current, the magnetic field strength in the motor is also constant. The torque produced by the motor is directly proportional to the strength of the magnetic field and the number of turns of the wire in the windings. Therefore, if the current is held constant, the torque produced will be directly proportional to the inductance of the windings, which is itself proportional to the number of turns of wire in the windings.

In summary, the relationship between torque and inductance in an electric motor depends on the operating conditions. If the current is constant, the torque will be directly proportional to the inductance, which in turn is proportional to the number of turns of wire in the windings. However, if the current is allowed to vary, the torque will be proportional to the square root of the inductance.
